articles.title: Contributing
articles.description: How you can help build FTOL
articles.contents:
FTOL is a community-driven project. Contributions are welcome!
Please do let us know if something in the tree appears to need correction.
The best way to make a contribution is to file an issue on the FTOL github repo.

articles.title: Downloads
articles.description: Current and past versions of FTOL available for download
articles.contents:
About the data
Tree format
FTOL is available in several flavors:
The maximum likelihood (ML) tree has branchlengths in units of expected genetic change per site.
The consensus tree is the extended majority-rule consensus of the bootstrap trees, with units in expected genetic change per site.
The dated tree has branchlengths in units of time (Ma) and is ultrametric.
The backbone ML tree only includes species that have complete plastome sequences available.
All trees are rooted on algae (Zygnema) and include outgroup taxa, but Zygnema has been pruned from the dated trees. Node labels are bootstrap support values (%) measured with ultra-fast bootstrap (Hoang et al. 2018).
All trees are in Newick format.
Other data files
The tree files are provided as part of a data archive (zip or tar.gz format).
Other files in the archive include DNA sequence alignments, GenBank accession numbers, and fossil calibration points.
All files are described in the README.txt file contained within the archive.
ftolr R pacakge
For reading the data directly into R with more options (rooting, inclusion of outgroup, selection of only part of the alignment, etc.), use the ftolr R package.
Current version: v1.1.0
Built with data from GenBank release 249 (cutoff date 2022-04-15).

articles.title: The Fern Tree of Life (FTOL)
articles.description: A webportal hosting the Fern Tree of Life and associated data
articles.contents:
The Fern Tree of Life (FTOL) is a global phylogeny of extant fern species based on plastid DNA sequences.
For a complete description, see Nitta et al. (2022).
FTOL is an on-going project and will be regularly updated as new sequence data become available.



Nitta, Joel H., Eric Schuettpelz, Santiago Ramírez-Barahona, and Wataru Iwasaki. 2022. “An Open and Continuously Updated Fern Tree of Life (FTOL).” BioRxiv, February. https://doi.org/10.1101/2022.03.31.486640.

articles.title: Methods
articles.description: Summary of methods used to infer phylogenies
articles.contents:
For a full description of methods, see Nitta et al. (2022).
The goal of this project is to produce a maximally sampled global fern phylogeny.
All DNA sequence data were downloaded from GenBank. The current FTOL (v1.1.0) includes sequences up to 2022-04-15 (GenBank release 249).
Input data, including a database containing fern sequences from GenBank release 249, are available on FigShare.
Two datasets were produced:
The “plastome” dataset includes 79 loci obtained from whole plastomes for 442 species (including outgroup taxa).
The “Sanger” dataset includes 7 plastid loci for 5,601 species (including outgroup taxa).
Phylogenetic analysis was carried out using maximum likelihood in IQ-TREE (Nguyen et al. 2015) in two steps. First, a backbone phylogeny was built using the plastome dataset. Next, the full phylogeny was built using the Sanger dataset with the backbone phylogeny as a constraint tree. For both analyses, all loci were concatenated and no partitioning was used.
The tree was dated using treePL (Smith and O’Meara 2012) with a set of 52 fossil constraints (not including the root).



Nguyen, Lam-Tung, Heiko A. Schmidt, Arndt von Haeseler, and Bui Quang Minh. 2015. “IQ-TREE: A Fast and Effective Stochastic Algorithm for Estimating Maximum-Likelihood Phylogenies.” Molecular Biology and Evolution 32 (1): 268–74. https://doi.org/10.1093/molbev/msu300.


Nitta, Joel H., Eric Schuettpelz, Santiago Ramírez-Barahona, and Wataru Iwasaki. 2022. “An Open and Continuously Updated Fern Tree of Life (FTOL).” BioRxiv, February. https://doi.org/10.1101/2022.03.31.486640.


Smith, Stephen A, and Brian C. O’Meara. 2012. “treePL: Divergence Time Estimation Using Penalized Likelihood for Large Phylogenies.” Bioinformatics 28 (20): 2689–90. https://doi.org/10.1093/bioinformatics/bts492.

articles.title: Data explorer
articles.contents:
Please use the FTOL data explorer web app (https://fernphy.shinyapps.io/ftol_explorer/) to easily access more information about particular species in the tree, including GenBank accessions and taxonomy.
Screenshot of FTOL explorer app

articles.title: Tree Viewer
articles.contents:
The interactive tree visualization below shows families (inner ring), suborders (middle ring), and orders (outer ring) on the dated, consensus tree (FTOL v1.1.0), with branches colored by family. Move the mouse over a colored bar to see the name of the family, subfamily or order. Species names are turned off by default but can be shown by adjusting settings in the Control Panel. Colored strips and branches can also be turned on or off under “Datasets”. The same visualization is available at Interactive Tree of Life.
For more detailed, faster viewing, we recommend downloading the tree and viewing it with Dendroscope3.
